comment.author: 38118929@N05
comment._content: It is so amazing to see the intricate tailoring of women's clothing from such a long period of time ago. I wish people still adorned themselves in this type of unique clothing!

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: This appears from the same event as the next picture of Miss M. Kennedy, which took place on January 10, 1911: "The first specialty show given by the American Pomeranian Club was held in the sun parlor of the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday with 262 silken-coated entries in the long rows of cages, which took up every available bit of space on the hotel roof garden. The number of dainty little Poms was unusually large and them attendance far exceeded the expectations of the club." query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9B07E4DB1331E233A... Mrs. George Russell Peabody is mentioned in the article as having been in attendance. She is listed in the "Woman's Who's Who In America 1914-15, page 630, as follows: PEABODY, Natalie Clews (Mrs. George Russell Peabody), Belle Hatch Park, Harpsden, Henley-on-Thames, England. Born July 30. 1890; dau. John Henry and Jessie (Bradley) Clews: ed. Miss Spence's School, N.Y. City; m. N.Y. City, Nov. 16, 1909, George Russell Peabody; one daughter: Natica Peabody. Episcopalian. Now living abroad. books.google.com/books?id=34hmAAAAMAAJ&source=gbs_nav... Marian Kennedy and Buttercup, from the same event:
